awd_titl_txt: PFI-RP: Smart and Accessible Transportation Hub for Assistive Navigation and Facility Management
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this PFI project lies in its ultimate goal to transform a large transportation hub into a smart and accessible hub (SAT-Hub), with minimal infrastructure change. The market opportunity is tremendous as there are various large transportation hubs in the United States. The solution can also be extended to indoor navigation of other public facilities, such as school buildings, libraries, office buildings, and airports. The project will lead to three important outcomes: live facility models for facility management by transportation agencies, free indoor positioning and navigation apps for end users, and a rich set of multimodal transportation data and tools for researchers and developers. The societal need is significant, especially impactful for people in great need, such as those with visual impairments and autism spectrum disorder (ASD), and those with challenges in finding places, particularly persons unfamiliar with metropolitan areas. In the U.S. alone, 6.6 million people have visual impairments, and 1 in 45 people have been diagnosed with ASD. The SAT-Hub will be an exemplar case to extend the reach of their mobility, give them more freedom, allow them to enhance the richness and quality of their lives, and improve their employment opportunities. 

The proposed project integrates an existing surveillance camera system, installed Bluetooth beacons, and a building information model of a transportation or other public facility, with a hybrid solution of a mobile phone localization app (using beacons, on-board sensors, and cameras along with 3D sensors). These will be incorporated with personalized user interfaces to provide a seamless service to the end users, while also providing valuable user information and facility use information to transportation infrastructure stakeholders.  Our solution is a system-engineering approach to a challenging problem in urban transportation that integrates three major components: multilayer live facility modeling tools, hybrid mobile navigation algorithms, and multimodal human-centric interface designs. The technology innovation lies in the integration of smart infrastructure (civil engineering) with accessible services (sensing and computing). The key technological challenges come from two sides: the seamless integration of the system with the main operations of a transportation or other facility base on obtaining information and data (such as surveillance data and 3D model data), and the optimization and personalization of user interfaces to address various user needs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The CUNY-Rutgers-Lighthouse Guild joint research team, in close collaboration with our primary industrial partner Bentley Systems, Inc., and three sectors of other partners or potential investors in transportation agencies, service institutions and local government agencies, aims to bring Smart and Accessible Transportation Hub (SAT-Hub) service to all, especially to people with disabilities. This has been achieved by tackling early technical challenges, exploring commercial potentials and undertaking customer discovery, engaging education and training for students, and accelerating innovations through partnerships. 

The team features strong interdisciplinary background and collective synergies in urban systems, infrastructure engineering, sensing/data analytics, accessibility considering perceptual/cognitive human factors, and paratransit services. We have leveraged several transportation facilities at the heart of New York City and the State of New Jersey, including NYC Port Authority, MTA, NJ Transit, and NJ Passaic County as testbeds for the proposed study. The SAT-Hub is designed as an integrated and human-centered cyber-physical infrastructure framework that can effectively and efficiently transform existing transportation hubs into smart facilities that are capable of providing better location-awareness and personalized navigation services (e.g. finding terminals, improving travel experience, obtaining security alerts) to the traveling public. Although we initially developed this for underserved sensory and cognitive loss populations, the system is able to enhance universal access for any indoor facilities. 

As the name of our proposed work indicated – Smart and Accessible Transportation Hub, the novelty of the work is the integration of three major elements: intelligence, accessibility, and transportation. Specifically, the intellectual impact of the work lies in at least three aspects:

(1) The innovative combination of indoor crowd/traffic analysis and 3D facility information for assisting localization and path planning. Using 3D for navigation and localization is a common practice in computer vision and robotics, and using active sensors for location-based services have been developed for people with disabilities. However, integration of crowd dynamic information with 3D static information is the first-of-its-kind work and key to providing customized paths for people with travel and mobility challenges.

(2) The focus of the work is the use of indoor crowd traffic analysis to better serve passengers in navigating through or away from crowds. There are many working on crowd and traffic analysis, but few of them are focused on assisting people with disabilities, especially in indoor environments. We have also developed novel algorithms based on generative adversarial networks (GANs) to use minimal labeled data for crowd analysis.

(3) The major goal of the project is smart transportation with accessibility. Even though smart transportation hubs under the umbrella of CPS and IOTs have been developed in many research organizations, they are either just designed for general public thus neglecting the accessibility of people with special needs, or only provide the first level of information to people with disabilities (e.g., the whereabouts in an airport for visually impaired people), without any consideration of the walkability of the paths and the crowd traffic information, which are crucial for people who are blind or have low vision, as well as other disabilities.

The SAT-Hub team has worked on customer discovery (through an NSF I-Corps project)  and has been identifying patentable technologies that can be transferred to industry applications. We have received a STTR Phase I grant through a CUNY spinoff Nearabl, Inc., which is the direct outcome of this PFI project. The spin-off company has obtained an exclusive license to commercialize the IP on multimodal indoor navigation, once again a direct outcome of this PFI project. Additional patents by current inventors and/or additional inventors may be licensed to create a more robust IP portfolio. 

The faculty and students have had opportunities to understand the needs of the communities, through this PFI grant. We have trained an array of students with different levels (PhD, masters, bachelors, and associate degrees) through research projects and summer research experiences, in partnerships with other programs such as NSF I-Corps, LSAMP and REUs at CCNY, BMCC and Rutgers. The students thus trained not only have a stronger sense in making breakthroughs in cross-disciplinary research through publications and theses, but also have a more urgent call for serving people with special needs, therefore doing good for society.
